title: javascript: and mailto: links are allowed in JIRA integration settings

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
For new feature settings, you accept website URLs like javascript:// or data:// in base urls. Even https://evil.com works, this needs to be stripped, this can be used to create another integrations without 

### Steps To Reproduce

1. https://hackerone.com/(Team)/integrations/jira/edit
2. Try in Base URL: javascript:// or data://
3. It will save and opens it everytime when escalate

### Optional: Your Environment (Browser version, Device, etc)
Works in all browsers
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
For new feature settings, you accept website URLs like javascript:// or data:// in base urls. Even https://evil.com works, this needs to be stripped, this can be used to create another integrations without

Steps To Reproduce

  1. https://hackerone.com/(Team)/integrations/jira/edit
  2. Try in Base URL: javascript:// or data://
  3. It will save and opens it everytime when escalate

Optional: Your Environment (Browser version, Device, etc)

Works in all browsers

activities.message:
Hi @jamesclyde,

I'm not able to reproduce the issue you're describing. 

I added the following content in the Base URL field: `javascript:alert(1)`, but when saving the page I get the following message: "Base URL is not valid".

How can I save the integration?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @jamesclyde,

I'm not able to reproduce the issue you're describing.

I added the following content in the Base URL field: javascript:alert(1), but when saving the page I get the following message: "Base URL is not valid".

How can I save the integration?

activities.message: There is an check at ://. So we can do javascript:// or mailto://. You need to make a check for this like only accepted protocols are https:// or http://.
activities.markdown_message: There is an check at ://. So we can do javascript:// or mailto://. You need to make a check for this like only accepted protocols are https:// or http://.

activities.message: Even `javascript://` didn't work for me. Can you please double check? We're unlikely to accept this as a security bug if you can just insert `javascript://`and not control anything after this.
activities.markdown_message: Even javascript:// didn't work for me. Can you please double check? We're unlikely to accept this as a security bug if you can just insert javascript://and not control anything after this.

activities.message:
Hi @jamesclyde,

It's not at all clear that your report is a duplicate of #212721. Note that #212721 had extremely detailed reproduction steps that allowed us to figure it out, while you did not respond to @asuka's request for more information.

We're sorry for not being able to understand your issue, but please be as detailed as possible in the future.

@reed This is not fair! How can this be duplicate of #212721? I told you that it was possible to inject javascript://.

The issue is javascript://alert(document.domain);%2f%2f@.

SO for sure his report is duplicate of mine! I reported it at 1 march 2017 and he reported it at march 12 2017.

So i reported it almost 2 weeks before him! So his report is a duplicate of mine. 

Can we full disclosure?

Again, we were not able to reproduce the issue with the information you provided, and you did not provide us follow-up information either.

We don't generally disclose duplicates, and I don't see any reason why this should be disclosed.

activities.message: The information you provided was not enough for two of my colleagues to reproduce the issue. Please make sure in the future to provide as much detail as possible when submitting an issue so that we can validate it and get it quickly fixed.

activities.message:
After some discussion internally, we're happy to offer you a small bounty for your report, as you were the first submitter (even though we could not confirm the issue based on your report).

In the future, please note that if you want us to consider a report more carefully, please provide a clear PoC with step-by-step instructions so that we may reproduce your finding.

Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:
After some discussion internally, we're happy to offer you a small bounty for your report, as you were the first submitter (even though we could not confirm the issue based on your report).

In the future, please note that if you want us to consider a report more carefully, please provide a clear PoC with step-by-step instructions so that we may reproduce your finding.

Happy hacking!
